item.title: The Basics of Assyian
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
In this lesson plan, you will learn and be introduced to the Assyrian alphabet, sounds, and vowels. This lesson plan is tailored for beginners and anyone looking to start their understanding of the language. Key highlights include:
  • The Assyrian Alphabet: Learn the 22 letters that make up the Assyrian script, each with its own unique sound and role.
  • Phonetics: Gain insights to the distinct sounds of the Assyrian language, focusing on its consonants and vowels that are essential for accurate pronunciation.
  • Vowels: Learn the difference between short and long vowels, and how they can change the sound of words and sentence flow.
This lesson plan goes over the topics above, in a summary format. These courses are designed for you to learn how to speak Assyrian, not necessarily read or write.

item.title: Introduction to the Assyrian Alphabet
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

By the end of this lesson, you will become familiar with the Assyrian alphabet, the sounds of each letter, and understanding the structure of words.

The Alphabet:

Here is the Assyrian Alphabet with their English equivalents. Each Assyrian letter is shown, named, then written how it would be spelled using the Latin script. A short description of pronunciation is also included.

ܐ - Alap (a, aa)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'A'. It has 3 distinct sounds used in Assyrian.
    • All
    • Dad (long a)
    • Apple (short a)

ܒ - Bet (b)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'B'.
    • Bat

ܓ - Gamal (g, j, gh)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'G'. It has 3 distinct sounds used in Assyrian.
    • Group
    • *One of the ways to pronounce Gamal is similar to the gargling sound when using mouthwash. In these cases, this sound will be written out as (gh)
    • Gym

ܕ - Dalat (d)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'D'.
    • Dude

ܗ - Heh (h)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'H'. It is similar to letting out a gentle breath.
    • Hole

ܘ - Waw (o, oo, wa)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'O'. It has 3 distinct sounds used in Assyrian.
    • Moon
    • Sore
    • When

ܙ - Zen (z)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'Z'.
    • Zebra

ܚ - Khet (kh)

  • There is no English equivalent to this sound.
    • The pronunciation is similar to the snoring sound. In this case, it will be written out as (kh). 

ܛ - Tet (T)

  • There is no English equivalent to this sound.
    • It is pronounced as a heavy 't' sound. In this case, it will be written out as (T).

ܝ - Yod (ee, ay, ya)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'I'.
    • Need
    • Pray
    • Yes 

ܟ - Kap (k, ch)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'K' and 'Ch'.
    • Key
    • Chop

ܠ - Lammad (l)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'L'.
    • Lean

ܡ - Meem (m)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'M'.
    • Map

ܢ - Noon (n)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'N'.
    • One

ܣ - Simket (s)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'S'.
    • South

ܥ - Eih (3)

  • There is no English equivalent to this sound. 
    • It is similar to the sound you make when the doctor checks your throat and tells you to make the "ah" sound but more guttural.
    • In this case, it will be written out as 3.

ܦ - Peh (p, f, v)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'P', 'F', and 'V'.
    • Pipe
    • Far
    • Vet

ܨ - Sadeh (S)

  • There is no English equivalent to this sound. It is a deeper version of the letter 'ss'.
    • Hiss (Deeper version of this sound, ss)
    • In this case, it will be written out as S. 

ܩ  - Qop (Q)

  • There is no English equivalent to this sound.
    • It is similar to the 'Q' sound but more guttural, using the top of the throat.
    • In this case, it will be written out as 'Q'.

ܪ  - Resh (r)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'R', except roll the 'r' like in Spanish.
    • Read

ܫ - Sheen (sh)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter "Sh".
    • Sheet

ܬ  - Taw (t, th)

  • This letter is the English equivalent to the letter 'T' and 'Th'.
    • Tower
    • Think

item.title: Introduction to Phonetics
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

By the end of this lesson, you will be able to accurately produce the various phonetic sounds of the Assyrian alphabet in different contexts and understand subtle variations in pronunciation. 

Phonetics: 

Vowel Length and Quality

  • Short vs Long Vowels: Practice distinguishing between short and long vowel sounds

  • Examples:

    • ܐ (a, aa) - Apple (short a) vs. Father (long a)

    • ܝ (ee, ay) - Need (long ee) vs. Bit (short i)

Consonant Clusters

  • Practice pronouncing clusters of consonants that occur in Assyrian

  • Examples:

    • ܨܦܵܝܝܼ (Spya) - Good

      • Phonetic breakdown: /s/ + /p/ + /y/ --- + /a/

      • This word is broken down into two syllables, spy, then a

    • ܟܬܵܒ݂ܵܐ (ktawa) - Book

      • Phonetic breakdown: /k/ + /t/ + /a/ --- + /w/ + /a/

      • This word is broken down into two syllables, kta, then wa

      • Notice that there is no vowel sound between the k sound and t sound

Voicing

  • Understand and practice the difference between voiced and voiceless consonants

  • Examples: 

    • Voiced: ܒ (b) as in Bat

      • Produced by vibrating the vocal cords while the lips are together then released

    • Voiceless: ܦ (p) as in Pat 

      • Produced by pressing the lips together then releasing them without vibrating the vocal cords

    • Voiced: ܓ (g) as in go

      • Produced by the back of the tongue against the soft palate, with vocal cord vibration

    • Voiceless: ܟ (k) as in key

      • Produced by the back of the tongue against the soft palate, without vocal cord vibration

    • Voiced: ܕ (d) as in dog

      • Produced by the back of the tongue against the soft palate, with vocal cord vibration

    • Voiceless: ܬ (t) as in top

      • Produced by the tongue against the alveolar ridge, without vocal cord vibration

  • Practice aspiration where applicable, like in ܦ (p), 

Letters and Sounds Not in English

  • ܚ - Khet (kh)

    • Phonetic description: Produced by narrowing the back of the throat and forcing air through it, similar to the sound made when clearing your throat

    • Example:

      • ܚܲܕ݇ (kha) - One

  • ܛ – Tet (T)

    • Phonetic description: A heavy 'T' sound produced by using the back of the tongue against the upper part of the mouth

    • Example:

      • ܛܲܝܪܵܐ (Tera) - Bird

  • ܥ – Eih (3)

    • Phonetic description: A guttural “ah” sound produced by tightening the throat and allowing air to pass through

    • Example:

      • ܥܲܝܢܵܐ (3ina) - Eye

  • ܨ – Sadeh (S)

    • Phonetic description: A deeper 'ss' sound produced with more force than the regular s

    • Example:

      • ܨܵܒܘܿܢ (Saboon) - Soap

  • ܩ – Qop (Q)

    • Phonetic Description: A guttural ‘Q’ sound produced by the back of the tongue against the soft palate with a guttural stop

    • Example:

      • ܩܵܫܵܐ (Qasha) - Priest

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
About

Welcome to Shlama, your online resource for learning the colloquial Assyrian language. Whether you are a heritage learning looking to connect with your roots, or a language enthusiast eager to explore a rich and vibrant language, Shlama offers a robust and engaging learning experience designed to meet your needs.

Learn More About the Assyrian People and Their Story

Assyrian History

The Assyrian language, a modern day spoken dialect of the Aramaic language, is one of the oldest continuously spoken languages in the world. Originating over 3,000 years ago in Mesopotamia, they have played a pivotal role in the development of human civilization. Aramaic was spoken all over the East and was widespread across several empires including the Assyrian, Babylonian, and Persian empires.

Assyrians have played a pivotal role in the development of art, science, law, and governance, with their innovations being used daily today. Our course delves into this past by bringing to life the monumental achievements of the Assyrian empire, its contributions to human knowledge, and the modern efforts to preserve Assyrian culture and heritage. By learning the Assyrian language, you connect with a legacy of scholars, warriors, and artisans whose impact on the world is still felt today.

Assyrian Culture

The ancient Assyrian culture and heritage has been kept alive today by modern Assyrians. Assyrian culture is a rich mosaic of historical customs, religious traditions, and contemporary community life. Learn about the traditional Assyrian arts, such as music, dance, and storytelling, which continue to be celebrated in festivals, gatherings, and churches throughout the world. The Assyrians have today maintain their cultural identity through language, cuisine, and arts, while also adapting to and influencing the global cultures they are apart of.

Our course provides a comprehensive look at how Assyrians have maintained their language, religion, and cultural customs, despite the constant challenges and oppression faced upon them. This journey through Assyrian culture not only educates, but also inspires, reflecting the unwavering resilience of a people who have navigated through history with resilience, strength, and unity.

Assyrian Dialects

About the Assyrian Dialects

Shlama strives to offer a comprehensive and accessible approach to learning the Assyrian language. While there are several dialects of Assyrian Neo-Aramaic, they can broadly be categorized into three groups: Eastern Assyrian, Central Assyrian, and Western Assyrian dialects.

Eastern Assyrian Dialects are vibrant and widely used. They include:

  • Chaldean: Spoken in parts of Iraq and Iran, known for their distinct culture and liturgical use in the Chaldean Catholic Church.
  • Nochiya: Tgus dialect comes from the Nochiya region and is noted for its distinctive phonetic traits.
  • Tiari: Originating from the Tiyari area in northern Iraq, Tiari boasts a rich oral tradition, making it especially vibrant and expressive.
  • Jilu: Spoken in the Jilu area in southeastern Turkey, this dialect is known for its unique expressions and vocabulary.
  • Baz: Native to the Baz district, it carries specific regional features that distinguish it from neighboring dialects.
  • Urmian: From around Lake Urmia in Northwestern Iran, Urmian serves as a lingua franca among Eastern Assyrian speakers and is considered a standard dialect.

Western Assyrian Dialects include:

  • Turoyo: This dialect is mainly used by Assyrians in the Tur Abdin area of southeastern Turkey and by diaspora communities in Europe and the Americas. Turoyo is dynamic, with several sub-dialects, adapting to both modern and traditional uses.

Western Aramaic:

Western Aramaic is predominantly historical today, and is used in many Assyrian churches to preserve the language. Western Aramaic dialects are revered for their ancient roots and still have some native speakers in a few villages in Syria, like Maaloula, where they preserve this linguistic heritage.

What Dialect Does Shlama Use?

In Shlama, we focus on a simplified colloquial version that can be understood by most native Assyrian speakers called Maleteh, regardless of their dialect. Chosen for its accessibility to beginners and its deep cultural resonance, Maleteh is spoken by Assyrians throughout the world, especially those living in diaspora including the US, Australia, Germany, etc. Many of the words and sounds in Shlama have been simplified for learners to grasp the complexity of the Assyrian language, while still being able to be understood by speakers around the world. An example of how we simplify many words can be seen like this:

  • ܒܰܝܬܳܐ : House
    • This word is traditionally pronounced Be'tha in Tiari dialect. In Shlama, we simplify this word by pronouncing it as Be'ta.
  • ܫܲܪܒ݂ܵܠܵܐ or ܬܘܼܢܒܵܢܵܐ : Pants
    • For pants, Tiari typically use the word shar'wa'la. In our simplified version, we teach the word tun'ba'na.

These are just a handful of examples of words that have been simplified in order for learners to memorize and pronounce words easier. In either case, these words are generally understood by native speakers of Assyrian.

Assyrian Christianity

Historical Background

Early Origins: Assyrian Christianity began in the ancient region of Mesopotamia, which encompasses modern-day Iraq, northeastern Syria, southeastern Turkey, and parts of Iran. According to tradition, the apostle Thomas and his disciples, Addai and Mari, brought Christianity to the Assyrians around AD 50-60. The Assyrian Church of the East was formally established in the first century, making it one of the earliest Christian communities.

Major Churches and Spread: Assyrian missionaries played a crucial role in spreading Christianity beyond their homeland, reaching as far as India and China by the 7th century. The Assyrian Church of the East is one of the most prominent denominations, following the ancient liturgical traditions and uses the Syriac language in its rites. The Chaldean Catholic Church was formed in the 16th century. This Assyrian church joined in communion with the Roman Catholic Church. This church maintains the traditions of the Assyrian Church but recognizes the authority and teaches of the Pope.

Challenges and Perseverance

Persecution and Diaspora: Assyrian Christians have faced significant persecution throughout history, including during the Ottoman Empire and throughout the modern era. Many were forced to flee their ancestral lands from the Muslims and Kurdish tribes in the area, resulting in widespread diaspora. In fact, the Assyrian Genocide (known as Sayfo) in the early 1900s, resulted in the death of nearly 75% of the entire Assyrian population. Despite these challenges, the Assyrian Christians have remained as one of the most resilient communities alive today, preserving their faith, cultural identity and unique history.

Ready to start your journey with the Assyrian language?

Join us at Shlama and start your Assyrian language journey today! Explore our course and become part of a community that celebrates Assyrian culture and heritage. If you have any questions, our team is just a click away on our Contact Us page.

Get Started

Privacy Policy

Effective Date: June 15, 2024
1. Introduction

Welcome to Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool ("Website"). We respect your privacy and are committed to protecting your personal information. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, and safeguard your information when you visit our Website. By using our Website, you agree to the terms of this Privacy Policy.

2. Information We Collect

We may collect the following types of information:

Cookies: We may use cookies to enhance your experience on our Website. Cookies are small data files stored on your device. You can choose to disable cookies through your browser settings, but this may affect your ability to use certain features of our Website.

Personal Information: When you create an account, sign up for our newsletter, or contact us, we may collect personal information such as your name, email address, and any other information you provide.

Usage Data: We may collect information about how you use our Website, including your IP address, browser type, operating system, pages visited, and the dates/times of your visits.

3. How We Use Your Information

We use the information we collect for the following purposes:

To Comply with Legal Obligations: We may use your information to comply with applicable laws and regulations.

To Provide and Improve Our Services: We use your information to operate and improve our Website and provide you with a better user experience.

To Communicate with You: We may use your contact information to send you updates, newsletters, and respond to your inquiries.

To Analyze Usage: We use usage data to understand how our Website is used and to make improvements.

4. Information Sharing and Disclosure

We do not sell, trade, or otherwise transfer your personal information to outside parties except in the following circumstances:

Protection of Rights: We may disclose your information to protect our rights, privacy, safety, or property, and/or that of our affiliates, you, or others.

Service Providers: We may share your information with third-party service providers who assist us in operating our Website and conducting our business. These service providers are required to keep your information confidential.

Legal Requirements: We may disclose your information if required to do so by law or in response to valid requests by public authorities.

5. Data Security

We implement reasonable security measures to protect your personal information from unauthorized access, use, or disclosure. However, no method of transmission over the Internet or method of electronic storage is completely secure, and we cannot guarantee absolute security.

6. Your Choices

You have the following choices regarding your personal information:

Delete Account: You can request the deletion of your account and personal information by contacting us.

Access and Update: You can access and update your personal information by logging into your account.

Opt-Out: You can opt-out of receiving our newsletter or marketing communications by following the unsubscribe instructions included in those emails or by contacting us directly.

7. Use of WordPress and Plugins

Our Website is built using WordPress and various plugins to enhance functionality and user experience. Some of these plugins may collect and process personal data. We ensure that any third-party plugins used are compliant with applicable privacy laws and have appropriate data protection measures in place. For detailed information on the data practices of these plugins, please refer to their respective privacy policies.

8. Educational Purposes

This Website is part of a capstone project for Grand Canyon University. The primary purpose of this Website is educational, aimed at providing a tool for learning the colloquial Assyrian language.

9. Third-Party Links

Our Website may contain links to third-party websites. We are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of these websites. We encourage you to review the privacy policies of any third-party sites you visit.

10. Children's Privacy

Our Website is not intended for children under the age of 13. We do not knowingly collect personal information from children under 13. If we become aware that we have collected personal information from a child under 13, we will take steps to delete such information.

11. Changes to This Privacy Policy

We may update this Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page. You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes.

12. Contact Us

If you have any questions or concerns about this Privacy Policy or our data practices, please contact us here.

item.title: Help Page
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Help Page

Welcome to the Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool Help Page!

We’re here to assist you with any questions or issues you may have while using our website. Below you'll find answers to frequently asked questions, as well as resources to help you make the most out of our tools.

1. Getting Started

Creating an Account

  • To create an account, click on the "Sign Up" button at the top right corner of the homepage. Fill in the required information and follow the prompts to complete the registration process.

Logging In

  • If you already have an account, click on the "Log In" button at the top right corner of the homepage. Enter your email and password to access your account.

2. Using the Website

Navigating the Website

  • The main menu at the top of the page allows you to navigate through different sections of the website, including lessons, resources, and your account settings.

Accessing Lessons

  • To access language lessons, click on the "Lessons" tab in the main menu. You will find a list of available lessons categorized by topic. Click on a lesson to start learning.

Using Resources

  • Our "Resources" section offers additional materials to support your learning. This includes dictionaries, pronunciation guides, and cultural insights.

3. Account Management

Updating Your Profile

  • To update your profile information, log in to your account and go to the "Account Settings" section. Here, you can update your personal information, change your password, and manage your preferences.

Resetting Your Password

  • If you forget your password, click on the "Forgot Password?" link on the login page. Enter your email address, and we will send you instructions to reset your password.

4. Troubleshooting

Common Issues

  • If you encounter any issues with the website, such as pages not loading or lessons not displaying correctly, try refreshing the page or clearing your browser cache. If the problem persists, please contact our support team here.

Contact Support

  • For further assistance, please reach out to our support team by filling out the Contact Us form. Include a detailed description of the issue you’re experiencing, and we will get back to you as soon as possible.

5. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

What languages are supported?

  • Currently, our website focuses on the colloquial Assyrian language from the English language. We may release lessons in an Arabic to Assyrian, German to Assyrian, and French to Assyrian format in the future.

Is there a mobile app available?

  • We are working on developing a mobile app to enhance your learning experience. Stay tuned for updates!

How can I provide feedback?

  • We value your feedback! Please send any comments or suggestions to the Feedback button on the Contact Us page. Your input helps us improve our services.

You can view more FAQs here.

7. Contact Us

If you have any questions or need further assistance, please contact us here.

Thank you for using Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool. We are here to support your language learning journey!

item.title: Simple Greetings & Phrases
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

By the end of this lesson, you will become familiar with Assyrian greetings and farewells and how these are pronounced. 

Greetings and Farewells:

Shlamalokh (ܫܠܵܡܵܐ ܠܘܼܟ݂) - Hello
  • Literally translates to 'Peace be upon you'.
  • Phonetic breakdown: /sh/ + /l/ + /a/ + /m/ + /a/ + /l/ + /o/ + /kh/
Da'kheet? (ܕܵܐܟ݂ܝ) - How are you?
  • Phonetic breakdown: /d/ + /a/, /kh/ + /ee/ + /t/
  • There are also specific responses to use when someone asks you this:
    • Spy (ܨܦܵܝ) - I'm good
    • Baseema (ܒܲܣܝܼܡܵܐ) - Thank you
      • Similar to saying I'm doing well but more polite
Allah minokh (ܐܲܠܵܗ ܡܸܢܘܼܟ݂) - Goodbye
  • Literally translates to 'God be with you'
  • Phonetic breakdown: /a/ + /l/ +/l/ + /ah/, /m/ + /i/ + /n/ + /l/ + /o/ + /kh/
Push B'Shena (ܦܘܫ ܒܫܝܢܐ) - Goodbye
  • Literally translates to 'Go in peace'
  • Phonetic breakdown: /p/ + /u/ + /sh/, /b/, /sh/ + /e/ + /n/ + /a/

item.title: Essential Grammar
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

This lesson introduces essential Assyrian grammar, focusing on personal pronouns and the formation of simple sentences. 

Personal Pronouns

Personal pronouns are words used to replace nouns and refer to people or things without naming them directly. In Assyrian, pronouns change based on the gender and number of the subject.

Ana (ܐܵܢܵܐ) - I
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to themselves
Ekhnan (ܐܸܚܢܵܢ) - Us
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to themselves and others
Atee (ܐܲܬܝ̈) - You
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to a person directly
Akhtokhun (ܐܲܚܬܘܿܟ݂ܘܢ) - You (pl.)
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to multiple people directly
Awen (ܐܲܘܢ) - Him
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to a male person or subject
Ayen (ܐܲܝ̈ܢ) - Her
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to a female person or subject
Anee (ܐܵܢܝܼ) - Them
  • This pronoun is used when the speaker is referring to multiple people or subjects

Using personal pronouns in a sentence can influence the structure and form of the words around them, particularly verbs and possessive nouns. This includes conjugation of verbs to match the pronoun and modifying nouns to show possession.

Ana eewen - I am
  • Example sentence: Ana eewen telmeeda (I am a student)
Ekhnen eewikh - We are
  • Example sentence: Ekhnan eewekh telmeedeh (We are students)
Atee eewit - You are
  • Example sentence: Atee eewit telmeeda (You are a student)
Akhtokhun eewotun - You (pl.) are
  • Example sentence: Akhtokhun eewotun telmeedeh (You are students)
Awen eeleh - He is
  • Example sentence: Awen eeleh telmeeda (He is a student)
Ayen eelah - She is
  • Example sentence: Ayen eelah telmeeda (She is a student)
Anee eelu - They are
  • Example sentence: Anee eelu telmeedeh (They are students)

item.title: Everyday Vocabulary
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

By the end of this lesson you will be able to expand your vocabulary knowledge, including common nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs.

Introduction to New Vocabulary:

Ana eewen goo shoola - I am at work

Ana - I

Eewen - am

Goo - at/in

Shoola - Work

 

Beta eela shiTrana - The house is pretty

Beta - House*

eela - is

ShiTrana - Beautiful

*Notice how there is no direct translate of the word “the” in Assyrian. “The” is often implied by context or through the use of suffixes and other grammatical structures. For example:

Kelba eele goo beta - The dog is in the house

Kelba - [The] dog

eele - is

goo - in

beta - [the] house

 

Words can also change based on their gender. This can be complicated very quickly, so we will start small for now. You probably already noticed the letter change above in “eela” vs “eele”. Eela is used for a feminine words while eele is used for masculine. Here are some more examples:

 

Zillokh (masculine) - Did you go?

Zillakh (feminine) - Did you go?

 

Zilleh beta (masculine) - He went home

Zillah beta (feminine) - She went home

 

Here are some important vocabulary words that are commonly used in everyday conversation:

Family Members

Mother - Yima

Father - Baba

Brother - Khona

Sister - Khata

Uncle - Khala (Maternal), 3mo (Paternal)

Aunt - Khaltah (Maternal), 3mta (Paternal)

Food

Food - Khalta

Drink - Shtehta

Water - Meya

Milk - Khalwa

Places

House - Beta

School - Medreshta

Church - 3umra

item.title: Sentence Structure
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

After this lesson, you will be able to structure grammatically correct sentences, by learning where to place words in a sentence.

Forming Sentences:

Forming sentences in Assyrian is a similar process to how it is in English. In both English and Assyrian sentences follow a Subject - Verb - Object (SVO) order. Here are some examples showing this structure and their similarities:

Atee (subj) Eewat (verb) Khoree (obj) - You (subj) are (verb) my friend (obj)

Ayen makhba aya beta - She likes this house

Ekhnan makhbikh aya beta - We like this house

Ana bayin auTnabil - I want a car

 

However, differences in the languages are present when adding in adjectives. In Assyrian, adjectives come after the noun, which is the opposite of English.

Khalta (noun) baseema (adj) - good food (khalta = food, baseema = good)

 

Here are a few more examples:

Yala Soora - a small boy (Yala = boy, Soora = small)

Brata shapirta - a pretty girl (Brata = girl, shapirta = pretty)

Riza Smooka - red rice (Riza = rice, Smooka = red)

Beta goora - a big house (beta = house, goora = big)

 

Now let’s add adjectives into our original sentences and see where they will be placed.

Ayen makhba aya beta + goora - She likes this big house

  • Notice how the adjective comes after the noun in a sentence?

Ekhnan makhbikh aya beta goora - We like this big house

Ana bayin auTnabil sowDana - I want a nice car

 

Now, when describing someone or something in a sentence using “eele/eela” (‘is’ in English), the sentence structure becomes similar to English again. For example:

Aya brata eela shapirta - this girl is pretty 

We can see word for word the sentence structure is the same (aya = this, brata = girl, eela = is, shapirta = pretty). Here are some more examples of this:

Awah yala eele Soora - this boy is small

Riza eele Smooka - The rice is red

Beta eele Soora - The house is small

item.title: Forming Questions
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Objective:

Learn how to correctly form sentences, using question words and previously learned vocabulary.

Forming Questions:

Basic vocabulary for forming questions

Ekkah? - Where?               Eeman? - When?

Manee? - Who?                  Dakhee? - How?

Moodee? - What?             Kamoo? - Why?

 

Common questions to learn:

Moodee bayyit [bayyat (f.)]? - What do you want?

Dakheewit [dakheewat (f.)]? - How are you?

Maneeleh [maneelah (f.)]? - Who is he(she)?

Ekkah ziloukh [zilakh (f.)]? - Where did you go?

Eeman azakh? - When are we going?

 

In Assyrian, the word that makes the sentence a question usually comes first, just like in English. However, verbs, nouns, and other words change structure based on the question, gender, and time.

How would we turn this sentence into a question? You are going home.

In Assyrian, this statement would be: Atee beezalat beta.

To make this a question (Are you going home?), we need to remove the pronoun "Atee". Since there isn't a word for "are you" in Assyrian, the question becomes: Beezalat beta?

 

Here are more examples of turning sentences into questions:

 

You are going - Atee't beezala

Where are you going? - Eekah beezalat?

 

She is calling - Maghboorilah

Who is she calling? - Mannee maghboorilah

 

You are eating - Atee't beekhalat

What are you eating? - Moode beekhalat?

 

You are doing- Atee't beewada

What are you doing? - Moode beewadat?

item.title: FAQs
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

1. What is Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool?

Shlama is an educational platform designed to help users learn the colloquial (spoken) Assyrian language. It provides lessons, resources, and tools to support language learning. "Shlama" in Assyrian is a way to say "hello", and it literally translates to "peace". The full greeting is "Shlamaloukh" or "peace be upon you".

2. How do I create an account?

To create an account, click on the "Sign Up" button at the top right corner of the homepage. You may also sign up by clicking the "Get Started" button on the homepage. Follow the prompts to complete the registration process.

3. How do I access the lessons?

Once logged in, navigate to the "Lessons" tab in the main menu. You will find a list of available lessons categorized by topic. Click on a lesson to start learning.

4. Are the lessons free?

Yes, all lessons on Shlama are free to access as part of our educational mission. We want to spread the Assyrian language and culture around the world to everyone without hiding it behind a paywall.

5. Can I track my learning progress?

Yes, once you are logged in, the system will keep track of your completed lessons and provide insights into your learning progress. You can save this progress by clicking "Mark as Complete" after learning the material on each page.

6. How do I reset my password?

If you forget your password, click on the "Forgot Password?" link on the login page. Enter your email address, and we will send you instructions to reset your password.

7. How can I provide feedback or suggest new features?

We value your feedback! Please send any comments or suggestions here. Your input helps us improve our services.

8. Is there a mobile app available?

We are working on developing a mobile app to enhance your learning experience. The website can also be ran on a phone through the phone's browser. Stay tuned for updates!

10. How can I contact support if I encounter an issue?

For further assistance, please reach out to our support team by reporting a problem here. Include a detailed description of the issue you’re experiencing, and we will get back to you as soon as possible.

11. What should I do if a lesson or page doesn’t load correctly?

If you encounter issues with the website, try refreshing the page or clearing your browser cache. If the problem persists, contact our support team.

12. Can I contribute content or become a tutor on Shlama?

We welcome contributions! If you are interested in contributing content or becoming a tutor, please contact us at for more information.

13. How do I update my profile information?

Log in to your account and go to the "Account Settings" section. Here, you can update your personal information, change your password, and manage your preferences.

14. What is the primary purpose of Shlama?

Shlama is part of a thesis or capstone project aimed at providing a tool for learning the colloquial Assyrian language.

item.title: Mission Page
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Shlama's Mission

Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool aims to preserve and promote the Assyrian language by providing accessible and engaging resources for children and individuals in the diaspora. Our mission is to empower the Assyrian community with the knowledge of their linguistic heritage, fostering a connection to their cultural roots and ensuring the continuity of the Assyrian language for future generations.

Vision

Our vision is to create a vibrant and supportive community of Assyrian language learners, where the language is not only preserved but also thrives in everyday use. We aim to see the Assyrian language embraced by new generations, keeping the rich cultural heritage alive and relevant.

Objectives

Increasing Accessibility: Provide quality, user-friendly resources for learning the Assyrian language in a simple and easy-to-learn format

Cultural Preservation: Ensure that the Assyrian language and cultural heritage are passed down to future generations

Community Building: Foster a sense of community among Assyrian language learners and speakers, even if you aren't Assyrian by blood

Educational Excellence: Develop a comprehensive lessons and interactive tools that facilitate effective language learning

item.title: About the Author
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
About the Author

Hello! I'm Nathan, the creator and developer of Shlama: Colloquial Assyrian Language Tool. As a passionate advocate for preserving and promoting the Assyrian language and culture, I have dedicated efforts into creating this resource to help others connect with their Assyrian heritage.

Background

I was born and raised in the United States where I grew up surrounded by my Assyrian family. I am 50% Tiriya, 25% Bazniya, and 25% Julwiya (different Assyrian villages). Growing up, my first language was Assyrian, however, as I got older, I noticed that I faced challenges in maintaining fluency in our native language while living in the diaspora.

Education and Experience

I hold a Masters Degree in Software Engineering from Grand Canyon University. My academic journey and professional experience have equipped me with the skills and knowledge necessary to develop comprehensive educational tools. Throughout my career, I have worked in various capacities within IT and education sectors, focusing on creating innovative solutions to meet diverse learning needs.

Inspiration

The inspiration for Shlama came from my personal experience and the stories of many other American Assyrians. Witnessing the gradual decline in the use of our native tongue among younger generations motivated me to take action. I wanted to create a platform that not only teaches the language but also celebrates our rich cultural heritage which has been attempted to be erased by numerous other groups.

Thank you for visiting Shlama and joining me in this journey to preserve and promote the Assyrian language and culture.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: nenwiya
item.content:encoded:
Learn the Assyrian Language

Shlama can help you learn how to read, write, and speak in the colloquial Assyrian language for non-native and native speakers.

Get Started

What will you learn

with Shlama?

Alphabet

Learn the Assyrian alphabet, from ܐ (Allap) to ܬ (Taw). Shlama's interactive lessons guide you through the unique sounds and shapes of the Assyrian script. With engaging exercises and real-life examples, you'll not only learn the alphabet, but also appreciate its artistic beauty.

Vocabulary

Expand your knowledge of the Assyrian language with new words and phrases that cover a wide range of topics, from everyday expressions to cultural expressions. Shlama will prepare you to engage in meaningful dialogues and deepen your connection with the Assyrian culture.

Grammar

Dive into the structure of the Assyrian language with our comprehensive grammar tutorials. From verb conjugations to sentence structure, our lessons are designed to build a solid foundation. Interactive quizzes and practical examples help you learn complex grammatical concepts.

Conversations

Practice Assyrian in real-life scenarios with our conversation-based lessons. From shopping to dining to socializing and navigating, Shlama prepares you to use Assyrian in everyday situations. Authentic dialogues and practical phrases equip you with the language skills needed to interact in the Assyrian speaking world.

Lesson Plan Timeline

  • Foundations

    Introduction to the Assyrian Alphabet

    Basic Phonetics and Pronunciation

    Simple Greetings and Phrases

    Essential Grammar Rules

  • Building Blocks

    Everyday Vocabulary Expansion

    Sentence Structure

    Forming Questions

    Introduction to Verbs and Tenses

  • Communication Skills

    Conversational Phrases and Responses

    Intermediate Grammar and Vocabulary

    Cultural Insights and Expressions

  • Advanced Language Use

    Complex Sentence Construction

    Advanced Verbal Forms and Tenses

    Expressing Opinions and Feelings

    Understanding Assyrian Literature and Media

What people are saying

"Shlama has improved my speaking skills and expanded my vocabulary of the Assyrian language! I have always spoken Assyrian, but love using Shlama to learn as much as I can about my culture and language.

Rami A.

"I have many Assyrians friends that can speak the language and after using Shlama, I can communicate with them as well. Assyrian is a hard language to learn but Shlama makes the learning experience as easy as possible.

Gordon H.

"Shlama has helped me expand my vocabulary so much! I always come here and practice learning a little bit everyday when I have some free time. It is really a fun and helpful tool that all Assyrians should check out."

Matthew E.

Want to help Shlama grow?

Donate Here

Contribute today to support Assyrian language education, ensuring Shlama remains free and without advertisements.
